# Solar wind

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

This article is about the [stellar wind](/wiki/Stellar_wind "Stellar wind")
from the [Sun](/wiki/Sun "Sun"). For other uses, see [Solar wind
(disambiguation)](/wiki/Solar_wind_\(disambiguation\) "Solar wind
\(disambiguation\)").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Solar_wind_Speed_interplanetary_magnetic_field.jpg/280px-
Solar_wind_Speed_interplanetary_magnetic_field.jpg)](/wiki/File:Solar_wind_Speed_interplanetary_magnetic_field.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Solar_wind_Speed_interplanetary_magnetic_field.jpg "Enlarge")

[_Ulysses_](/wiki/Ulysses_\(spacecraft\) "Ulysses \(spacecraft\)")'
observations of solar wind speed as a function of helio latitude during solar
minimum. Slow wind (≈400 km/s) is confined to the equatorial regions, while
fast wind (≈750 km/s) is seen over the poles.[1] Red/blue colors show
inward/outward polarities of the [heliospheric magnetic
field](/wiki/Interplanetary_magnetic_field "Interplanetary magnetic field").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Sun_poster.svg/320px-
Sun_poster.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Sun_poster.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Sun_poster.svg "Enlarge")

An illustration of the structure of the [Sun](/wiki/Sun "Sun")

  * [Granules](/wiki/Granule_\(solar_physics\) "Granule \(solar physics\)")
  * [Sunspot](/wiki/Sunspot "Sunspot")
  * [Photosphere](/wiki/Photosphere "Photosphere")
  * [Chromosphere](/wiki/Chromosphere "Chromosphere")
  * [Convection zone](/wiki/Convection_zone "Convection zone")
  * [Radiation zone](/wiki/Radiation_zone "Radiation zone")
  * [Tachocline](/wiki/Tachocline "Tachocline")
  * [Solar core](/wiki/Solar_core "Solar core")
  * [Corona](/wiki/Corona "Corona")
  * [Flare](/wiki/Solar_flare "Solar flare")
  * [Prominence](/wiki/Solar_prominence "Solar prominence")
  * Solar wind

The **solar wind** is a stream of [charged particles](/wiki/Charged_particle
"Charged particle") released from the upper [atmosphere of the
Sun](/wiki/Atmosphere_of_the_Sun "Atmosphere of the Sun"), called the
[corona](/wiki/Corona "Corona"). This [plasma](/wiki/Plasma_\(physics\)
"Plasma \(physics\)") consists of mostly [electrons](/wiki/Electron
"Electron"), [protons](/wiki/Proton "Proton") and [alpha
particles](/wiki/Alpha_particle "Alpha particle") with [kinetic
energy](/wiki/Kinetic_energy "Kinetic energy") between 0.5 and 10
[keV](/wiki/Electronvolt "Electronvolt"). Embedded within the solar-wind
plasma is the [interplanetary magnetic
field](/wiki/Interplanetary_magnetic_field "Interplanetary magnetic
field").[2] The solar wind varies in [density](/wiki/Density "Density"),
[temperature](/wiki/Temperature "Temperature") and [speed](/wiki/Speed
"Speed") over time and over solar latitude and longitude. Its particles can
escape the Sun's [gravity](/wiki/Gravity "Gravity") because of their high
energy resulting from the high temperature of the corona, which in turn is a
result of the coronal magnetic field.

At a distance of more than a few solar radii from the Sun, the solar wind is
[supersonic](/wiki/Supersonic "Supersonic") and reaches speeds of 250 to 750
kilometers per second.[3] The flow of the solar wind is no longer supersonic
at the [termination shock](/wiki/Termination_shock "Termination shock"). The
_[Voyager 2](/wiki/Voyager_2 "Voyager 2")_ spacecraft crossed the shock more
than five times between 30 August and 10 December 2007.[4] _Voyager 2_ crossed
the shock about a billion kilometers closer to the Sun than the 13.5-billion-
kilometer distance where _[Voyager 1](/wiki/Voyager_1 "Voyager 1")_ came upon
the termination shock.[5][6] The spacecraft moved outward through the
termination shock into the [heliosheath](/wiki/Heliosheath "Heliosheath") and
onward toward the [interstellar medium](/wiki/Interstellar_medium
"Interstellar medium"). Other related phenomena include the
[aurora](/wiki/Aurora_\(astronomy\) "Aurora \(astronomy\)")
([northern](/wiki/Aurora_Borealis "Aurora Borealis") and [southern
lights](/wiki/Aurora_Australis "Aurora Australis")), the
[plasma](/wiki/Plasma_\(physics\) "Plasma \(physics\)") tails of
[comets](/wiki/Comet "Comet") that always point away from the Sun, and
[geomagnetic storms](/wiki/Geomagnetic_storm "Geomagnetic storm") that can
change the direction of magnetic field lines.

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Solar_wind&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: History")]

The existence of particles flowing outward from the [Sun](/wiki/Sun "Sun") to
the Earth was first suggested by British astronomer [Richard C.
Carrington](/wiki/Richard_Christopher_Carrington "Richard Christopher
Carrington"). In [1859, Carrington and Richard Hodgson independently made the
first observation](/wiki/Solar_storm_of_1859 "Solar storm of 1859") of what
would later be called a [solar flare](/wiki/Solar_flare "Solar flare"). This
is a sudden, localised increase in brightness on the solar disc, which is now
known[7] to often occur in conjunction with an episodic ejection of material
and magnetic flux from the Sun's atmosphere, known as a [coronal mass
ejection](/wiki/Coronal_mass_ejection "Coronal mass ejection"). On the
following day, a [geomagnetic storm](/wiki/Geomagnetic_storm "Geomagnetic
storm") was observed, and Carrington suspected that there might be a
connection, which is now attributed to the arrival of the coronal mass
ejection in near-Earth space and its subsequent interaction with the Earth's
magnetosphere. [George FitzGerald](/wiki/George_Francis_FitzGerald "George
Francis FitzGerald") later suggested that matter was being regularly
accelerated away from the Sun and was reaching the Earth after several
days.[8]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Birkeland-anode-
globe-fig259.jpg/250px-Birkeland-anode-globe-
fig259.jpg)](/wiki/File:Birkeland-anode-globe-fig259.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Birkeland-anode-globe-fig259.jpg "Enlarge")

Laboratory simulation of the magnetosphere's influence on the Solar Wind;
these auroral-like [Birkeland currents](/wiki/Birkeland_current "Birkeland
current") were created in a [terrella](/wiki/Terrella "Terrella"), a
magnetised anode globe in an evacuated chamber.

In 1910 British astrophysicist [Arthur Eddington](/wiki/Arthur_Eddington
"Arthur Eddington") essentially suggested the existence of the solar wind,
without naming it, in a footnote to an article on [Comet
Morehouse](/wiki/Comet_Morehouse "Comet Morehouse").[9] The idea never fully
caught on even though Eddington had also made a similar suggestion at a Royal
Institution address the previous year. In the latter case, he postulated that
the ejected material consisted of electrons while in his study of Comet
Morehouse he supposed them to be [ions](/wiki/Ion "Ion").[9]

The first person to suggest that the ejected material consisted of both ions
and electrons was [Kristian Birkeland](/wiki/Kristian_Birkeland "Kristian
Birkeland").[10] His geomagnetic surveys showed that auroral activity was
nearly uninterrupted. As these displays and other geomagnetic activity were
being produced by particles from the Sun, he concluded that the Earth was
being continually bombarded by "rays of electric corpuscles emitted by the
Sun".[8] In 1916, Birkeland proposed that, "From a physical point of view it
is most probable that solar rays are neither exclusively negative nor positive
rays, but of both kinds". In other words, the solar wind consists of both
negative electrons and positive [ions](/wiki/Ions "Ions").[11] Three years
later in 1919, [Frederick Lindemann](/wiki/Frederick_Lindemann "Frederick
Lindemann") also suggested that particles of both polarities, protons as well
as electrons, come from the Sun.[12]

Around the 1930s, scientists had determined that the temperature of the solar
[corona](/wiki/Corona "Corona") must be a million degrees
[Celsius](/wiki/Anders_Celsius "Anders Celsius") because of the way it stood
out into space (as seen during total eclipses). Later spectroscopic work
confirmed this extraordinary temperature. In the mid-1950s [Sydney
Chapman](/wiki/Sydney_Chapman_\(astronomer\) "Sydney Chapman \(astronomer\)")
calculated the properties of a gas at such a temperature and determined it was
such a superb conductor of heat that it must extend way out into space, beyond
the orbit of Earth. Also in the 1950s, [Ludwig Biermann](/wiki/Ludwig_Biermann
"Ludwig Biermann") became interested in the fact that no matter whether a
[comet](/wiki/Comet "Comet") is headed towards or away from the Sun, its tail
always points away from the Sun. Biermann postulated that this happens because
the Sun emits a steady stream of particles that pushes the comet's tail
away.[13] Wilfried Schröder claimed that [Paul
Ahnert](/wiki/Paul_Oswald_Ahnert "Paul Oswald Ahnert") was the first to relate
solar wind to comet tail direction based on observations of the comet Whipple-
Fedke (1942g).[14]

[Eugene Parker](/wiki/Eugene_Parker "Eugene Parker") realised heat flowing
from the Sun in Chapman's model and the comet tail blowing away from the Sun
in Biermann's hypothesis had to be the result of the same phenomenon, which he
termed the "solar wind".[15][16] In 1957, Parker showed, even though the Sun's
corona is strongly attracted by solar gravity, it is such a good heat
conductor that it is still very hot at large distances. Since gravity weakens
as distance from the Sun increases, the outer coronal atmosphere escapes
supersonically into interstellar space. Furthermore, Parker was the first
person to notice that the weakening effect of the gravity has the same effect
on [hydrodynamic](/wiki/Hydrodynamic "Hydrodynamic") flow as a [de Laval
nozzle](/wiki/De_Laval_nozzle "De Laval nozzle"): it incites a transition from
[subsonic](/wiki/Speed_of_sound "Speed of sound") to
[supersonic](/wiki/Supersonic "Supersonic") flow.[17]

Opposition to Parker's hypothesis on the solar wind was strong. The paper he
submitted to _[The Astrophysical Journal](/wiki/The_Astrophysical_Journal "The
Astrophysical Journal")_ in 1958 was rejected by two reviewers. It was saved
by the editor [Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar](/wiki/Subrahmanyan_Chandrasekhar
"Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar").

In January 1959, the [Soviet](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union") spacecraft
_[Luna 1](/wiki/Luna_1 "Luna 1")_ first directly observed the solar wind and
measured its strength,[18][19][20] using hemispherical ion traps. The
discovery, made by Konstantin Gringauz, was verified by _[Luna 2](/wiki/Luna_2
"Luna 2")_ , _[Luna 3](/wiki/Luna_3 "Luna 3")_ and by the more distant
measurements of _[Venera 1](/wiki/Venera_1 "Venera 1")_. Three years later a
similar measurement was performed by Neugebauer and collaborators using the
_[Mariner 2](/wiki/Mariner_2 "Mariner 2")_ spacecraft.[21]

In the late 1990s, the Ultraviolet Coronal Spectrometer (UVCS) instrument on
board the [SOHO](/wiki/Solar_and_Heliospheric_Observatory "Solar and
Heliospheric Observatory") spacecraft observed the acceleration region of the
fast solar wind emanating from the poles of the Sun and found that the wind
accelerates much faster than can be accounted for by thermodynamic expansion
alone. Parker's model predicted that the wind should make the transition to
supersonic flow at an altitude of about 4 solar radii from the
[photosphere](/wiki/Photosphere "Photosphere") (surface); but the transition
(or "sonic point") now appears to be much lower, perhaps only 1 solar radius
above the photosphere, suggesting that some additional mechanism accelerates
the solar wind away from the Sun. The acceleration of the fast wind is still
not understood and cannot be fully explained by Parker's theory. The
gravitational and electromagnetic explanation for this acceleration is,
however, detailed in an earlier paper by 1970 [Nobel
laureate](/wiki/List_of_Nobel_laureates "List of Nobel laureates") for
[Physics](/wiki/Physics "Physics"), [Hannes Alfvén](/wiki/Hannes_Alfv%C3%A9n
"Hannes Alfvén").[22][23]

The first numerical simulation of the solar wind in the solar
[corona](/wiki/Corona "Corona") including [closed and open field
lines](/wiki/Magnetic_field "Magnetic field") was performed by Pneuman and
Kopp in 1971. The [magnetohydrodynamics](/wiki/Magnetohydrodynamics
"Magnetohydrodynamics") equations in [steady state](/wiki/Steady_state "Steady
state") were solved iteratively starting with an initial
[dipolar](/wiki/Dipole "Dipole") configuration.[24]

In 1990, the [_Ulysses_](/wiki/Ulysses_\(spacecraft\) "Ulysses
\(spacecraft\)") probe was launched to study the solar wind from high solar
latitudes. All prior observations had been made at or near the Solar System's
[ecliptic](/wiki/Ecliptic "Ecliptic") plane.[25]

In 2018, NASA launched the [Parker Solar Probe](/wiki/Parker_Solar_Probe
"Parker Solar Probe"), named in honor of Eugene Parker, on a mission to study
the structure and dynamics of the solar corona, in an attempt to understand
the mechanisms that cause particles to be heated and accelerated as solar
wind. During its seven year mission, the probe will make twenty-four orbits of
the sun, passing further into the corona with each orbit's
[perihelion](/wiki/Perihelion "Perihelion"), ultimately passing within 0.04
[astronomical units](/wiki/Astronomical_units "Astronomical units") of the
sun's surface. It is the first NASA spacecraft named for a living person, and
Parker himself, at age 91, was on hand to observe the launch.[26]

## Acceleration[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Solar_wind&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Acceleration")]

While early models of the solar wind relied primarily on
[thermal](/wiki/Thermal "Thermal") energy to accelerate the material, by the
1960s it was clear that thermal acceleration alone cannot account for the high
speed of solar wind. An additional unknown acceleration mechanism is required
and likely relates to [magnetic fields](/wiki/Magnetic_field "Magnetic field")
in the solar atmosphere.

The Sun's [corona](/wiki/Corona "Corona"), or extended outer layer, is a
region of plasma that is heated to over a million [kelvin](/wiki/Kelvin
"Kelvin"). As a result of thermal collisions, the particles within the inner
corona have a range and distribution of speeds described by a [Maxwellian
distribution](/wiki/Maxwell%E2%80%93Boltzmann_distribution "Maxwell–Boltzmann
distribution"). The mean velocity of these particles is about 145 km/s, which
is well below the solar [escape velocity](/wiki/Escape_velocity "Escape
velocity") of 618 km/s. However, a few of the particles achieve energies
sufficient to reach the terminal velocity of 400 km/s, which allows them to
feed the solar wind. At the same temperature, electrons, due to their much
smaller mass, reach escape velocity and build up an electric field that
further accelerates ions away from the Sun.[27]

The total number of particles carried away from the Sun by the solar wind is
about 1.3×1036 per second.[28] Thus, the total mass loss each year is about
(2–3)×10−14 [solar masses](/wiki/Solar_mass "Solar mass"),[29] or about
(1.3–1.9) million tonnes per second. This is equivalent to losing a mass equal
to the Earth every 150 million years.[30] However, only about 0.01% of the
Sun's total mass has been lost through the solar wind.[31] Other stars have
much stronger [stellar winds](/wiki/Stellar_wind "Stellar wind") that result
in significantly higher mass loss rates.

## Properties and
structure[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Solar_wind&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Properties and structure")]

### Fast and slow solar
wind[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Solar_wind&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section:
Fast and slow solar wind")]

The solar wind is observed to exist in two fundamental states, termed the slow
solar wind and the fast solar wind, though their differences extend well
beyond their speeds. In near-Earth space, the slow solar wind is observed to
have a velocity of 300–500 km/s, a temperature of 1.4–1.6×106 K and a
composition that is a close match to the [corona](/wiki/Corona "Corona"). By
contrast, the fast solar wind has a typical velocity of 750 km/s, a
temperature of 8×105 K and it nearly matches the composition of the Sun's
[photosphere](/wiki/Photosphere "Photosphere").[32] The slow solar wind is
twice as dense and more variable in nature than the fast solar wind.[28][33]

The slow solar wind appears to originate from a region around the Sun's
equatorial belt that is known as the "streamer belt", where coronal streamers
are produced by magnetic flux open to the heliosphere draping over closed
magnetic loops. The exact coronal structures involved in slow solar wind
formation and the method by which the material is released is still under
debate.[34][35][36] Observations of the Sun between 1996 and 2001 showed that
emission of the slow solar wind occurred at latitudes up to 30–35° during the
[solar minimum](/wiki/Solar_minimum "Solar minimum") (the period of lowest
solar activity), then expanded toward the poles as the solar cycle approached
maximum. At [solar maximum](/wiki/Solar_maximum "Solar maximum"), the poles
were also emitting a slow solar wind.[1]

The fast solar wind originates from [coronal holes](/wiki/Coronal_hole
"Coronal hole"),[37] which are funnel-like regions of open field lines in the
Sun's [magnetic field](/wiki/Magnetic_field "Magnetic field").[38] Such open
lines are particularly prevalent around the Sun's magnetic poles. The plasma
source is small magnetic fields created by [convection
cells](/wiki/Convection_cell "Convection cell") in the solar atmosphere. These
fields confine the plasma and transport it into the narrow necks of the
coronal funnels, which are located only 20,000 kilometers above the
photosphere. The plasma is released into the funnel when these magnetic field
lines reconnect.[39]

### Pressure[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Solar_wind&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Pressure")]

The wind exerts a pressure at 1 [AU](/wiki/Astronomical_unit "Astronomical
unit") typically in the range of 1–6 nPa (1–6×10−9 N/m2), although it can
readily vary outside that range.

The [ram pressure](/wiki/Ram_pressure "Ram pressure") is a
[function](/wiki/Function_\(mathematics\) "Function \(mathematics\)") of wind
speed and density. The formula is

P = mp * n * V2= 1.6726×10−6 * n * V2

where mp is the [proton](/wiki/Proton "Proton") mass, pressure P is in nPa
(nanopascals), n is the density in particles/cm3 and V is the speed in km/s of
the solar wind.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_][40]

### Coronal mass
ejection[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Solar_wind&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Coronal mass ejection")]

Main article: [Coronal mass ejection](/wiki/Coronal_mass_ejection "Coronal
mass ejection")

Both the fast and slow solar wind can be interrupted by large, fast-moving
bursts of plasma called [interplanetary coronal mass
ejections](/wiki/Coronal_mass_ejection "Coronal mass ejection"), or ICMEs.
ICMEs are the interplanetary manifestation of solar [coronal mass
ejections](/wiki/Coronal_mass_ejections "Coronal mass ejections"), which are
caused by release of magnetic energy at the Sun. CMEs are often called "solar
storms" or "space storms" in the popular media. They are sometimes, but not
always, associated with [solar flares](/wiki/Solar_flare "Solar flare"), which
are another manifestation of magnetic energy release at the Sun. ICMEs cause
shock waves in the thin plasma of the heliosphere, launching electromagnetic
[waves](/wiki/Wave "Wave") and accelerating particles (mostly
[protons](/wiki/Proton "Proton") and [electrons](/wiki/Electrons "Electrons"))
to form showers of [ionizing radiation](/wiki/Ionizing_radiation "Ionizing
radiation") that precede the CME.

When a CME impacts the Earth's [magnetosphere](/wiki/Magnetosphere
"Magnetosphere"), it temporarily deforms the Earth's [magnetic
field](/wiki/Magnetic_field "Magnetic field"), changing the direction of
[compass](/wiki/Compass "Compass") needles and inducing large electrical
ground currents in Earth itself; this is called a [geomagnetic
storm](/wiki/Geomagnetic_storm "Geomagnetic storm") and it is a global
phenomenon. CME impacts can induce [magnetic
reconnection](/wiki/Magnetic_reconnection "Magnetic reconnection") in Earth's
[magnetotail](/wiki/Magnetosphere#Magnetic_tails "Magnetosphere") (the
midnight side of the [magnetosphere](/wiki/Magnetosphere "Magnetosphere"));
this launches protons and electrons downward toward Earth's atmosphere, where
they form the [aurora](/wiki/Aurora_\(phenomenon\) "Aurora \(phenomenon\)").

ICMEs are not the only cause of [space weather](/wiki/Space_weather "Space
weather"). Different patches on the Sun are known to give rise to slightly
different speeds and densities of wind depending on local conditions. In
isolation, each of these different wind streams would form a spiral with a
slightly different angle, with fast-moving streams moving out more directly
and slow-moving streams wrapping more around the Sun. Fast moving streams tend
to overtake slower streams that originate [westward](/wiki/West "West") of
them on the Sun, forming turbulent co-rotating interaction regions that give
rise to wave motions and accelerated particles, and that affect Earth's
magnetosphere in the same way as, but more gently than, CMEs.

## Solar System
effects[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Solar_wind&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Solar System effects")]

Main article: [Space weather](/wiki/Space_weather "Space weather")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Heliospheric-current-
sheet.gif/250px-Heliospheric-current-sheet.gif)](/wiki/File:Heliospheric-
current-sheet.gif)

[](/wiki/File:Heliospheric-current-sheet.gif "Enlarge")

The [heliospheric current sheet](/wiki/Heliospheric_current_sheet
"Heliospheric current sheet") results from the influence of the Sun's rotating
magnetic field on the plasma in the solar wind

Over the Sun's lifetime, the interaction of its surface layers with the
escaping solar wind has significantly decreased its surface rotation rate.[41]
The wind is considered responsible for comets' tails, along with the Sun's
radiation.[42] The solar wind contributes to fluctuations in
[celestial](/wiki/Sky "Sky") [radio waves](/wiki/Radio_wave "Radio wave")
observed on the Earth, through an effect called [interplanetary
scintillation](/wiki/Interplanetary_scintillation "Interplanetary
scintillation").[43]

### Magnetospheres[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Solar_wind&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Magnetospheres")]

Main article: [Magnetosphere](/wiki/Magnetosphere "Magnetosphere")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Structure_of_the_magnetosphere-
en.svg/330px-Structure_of_the_magnetosphere-
en.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Structure_of_the_magnetosphere-en.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Structure_of_the_magnetosphere-en.svg "Enlarge")

Schematic of Earth's [magnetosphere](/wiki/Magnetosphere "Magnetosphere"). The
solar wind flows from left to right.

Where the solar wind intersects with a planet that has a well-developed
[magnetic field](/wiki/Magnetic_field "Magnetic field") (such as Earth,
Jupiter or Saturn), the particles are deflected by the [Lorentz
force](/wiki/Lorentz_force "Lorentz force"). This region, known as the
[magnetosphere](/wiki/Magnetosphere "Magnetosphere"), causes the particles to
travel around the planet rather than bombarding the atmosphere or surface. The
magnetosphere is roughly shaped like a [hemisphere](/wiki/Sphere "Sphere") on
the side facing the Sun, then is drawn out in a long wake on the opposite
side. The boundary of this region is called the
[magnetopause](/wiki/Magnetopause "Magnetopause"), and some of the particles
are able to penetrate the magnetosphere through this region by partial
reconnection of the magnetic field lines.[27]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Solar_Wind_and_Earth%27s_magnetic_field.png/220px-
Solar_Wind_and_Earth%27s_magnetic_field.png)](/wiki/File:Solar_Wind_and_Earth%27s_magnetic_field.png)

[](/wiki/File:Solar_Wind_and_Earth%27s_magnetic_field.png "Enlarge")

Noon meridian section of magnetosphere

The solar wind is responsible for the overall shape of Earth's magnetosphere.
Fluctuations in its speed, density, direction, and [entrained magnetic
field](/wiki/Interplanetary_magnetic_field "Interplanetary magnetic field")
strongly affect Earth's local space environment. For example, the levels of
ionizing radiation and radio interference can vary by factors of hundreds to
thousands; and the shape and location of the magnetopause and bow [shock
wave](/wiki/Shock_wave "Shock wave") upstream of it can change by several
Earth radii, exposing [geosynchronous](/wiki/Geosynchronous_orbit
"Geosynchronous orbit") satellites to the direct solar wind. These phenomena
are collectively called [space weather](/wiki/Space_weather "Space weather").

From the [European Space Agency](/wiki/European_Space_Agency "European Space
Agency")'s [Cluster](/wiki/Cluster_II_\(spacecraft\) "Cluster II
\(spacecraft\)") mission, a new study has taken place that proposes that it is
easier for the solar wind to infiltrate the magnetosphere than previously
believed. A group of scientists directly observed the existence of certain
waves in the solar wind that were not expected. A recent study shows that
these waves enable incoming charged particles of solar wind to breach the
magnetopause. This suggests that the magnetic bubble forms more as a filter
than a continuous barrier. This latest discovery occurred through the
distinctive arrangement of the four identical Cluster spacecraft, which fly in
a controlled configuration through near-Earth space. As they sweep from the
magnetosphere into interplanetary space and back again, the fleet provides
exceptional three-dimensional insights on the phenomena that connect the sun
to Earth.

The research characterised variances in formation of the [interplanetary
magnetic field](/wiki/Interplanetary_magnetic_field "Interplanetary magnetic
field") (IMF) largely influenced by [Kelvin–Helmholtz
instability](/wiki/Kelvin%E2%80%93Helmholtz_instability "Kelvin–Helmholtz
instability") (which occur at the interface of two fluids) as a result of
differences in thickness and numerous other characteristics of the boundary
layer. Experts believe that this was the first occasion that the appearance of
Kelvin-Helmholtz waves at the magnetopause had been displayed at high latitude
dawnward orientation of the IMF. These waves are being seen in unforeseen
places under solar wind conditions that were formerly believed to be undesired
for their generation. These discoveries show how Earth's magnetosphere can be
penetrated by solar particles under specific IMF circumstances. The findings
are also relevant to studies of magnetospheric progressions around other
planetary bodies. This study suggests that Kelvin-Helmholtz waves can be a
somewhat common, and possibly constant, instrument for the entrance of solar
wind into terrestrial magnetospheres under various IMF orientations.[44]

### Atmospheres[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Solar_wind&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Atmospheres")]

The solar wind affects other incoming [cosmic rays](/wiki/Cosmic_ray "Cosmic
ray") interacting with planetary atmospheres. Moreover, planets with a weak or
non-existent magnetosphere are subject to atmospheric stripping by the solar
wind.

[Venus](/wiki/Venus "Venus"), the nearest and most similar planet to Earth,
has 100 times denser atmosphere, with little or no geo-magnetic field. Space
probes discovered a comet-like tail that extends to Earth's orbit.[45]

Earth itself is largely protected from the solar wind by [its magnetic
field](/wiki/Earth%27s_magnetic_field "Earth's magnetic field"), which
deflects most of the charged particles; however some of the charged particles
are trapped in the [Van Allen radiation belt](/wiki/Van_Allen_radiation_belt
"Van Allen radiation belt"). A smaller number of particles from the solar wind
manage to travel, as though on an electromagnetic energy transmission line, to
the Earth's upper atmosphere and [ionosphere](/wiki/Ionosphere "Ionosphere")
in the auroral zones. The only time the solar wind is observable on the Earth
is when it is strong enough to produce phenomena such as the
[aurora](/wiki/Aurora_\(astronomy\) "Aurora \(astronomy\)") and [geomagnetic
storms](/wiki/Geomagnetic_storm "Geomagnetic storm"). Bright auroras strongly
heat the ionosphere, causing its plasma to expand into the magnetosphere,
increasing the size of the plasma [geosphere](/wiki/Geosphere "Geosphere") and
injecting atmospheric matter into the solar wind. [Geomagnetic
storms](/wiki/Geomagnetic_storm "Geomagnetic storm") result when the pressure
of plasmas contained inside the magnetosphere is sufficiently large to inflate
and thereby distort the geomagnetic field.

Although [Mars](/wiki/Mars "Mars") is larger than Mercury and four times
farther from the Sun, it is thought that the solar wind has stripped away up
to a third of its original atmosphere, leaving a layer 1/100th as dense as the
Earth's. It is believed the mechanism for this atmospheric stripping is gas
caught in bubbles of magnetic field, which are ripped off by solar winds.[46]
In 2015 the NASA Mars Atmosphere and Volatile Evolution ([MAVEN](/wiki/MAVEN
"MAVEN")) mission measured the rate of atmospheric stripping caused by the
magnetic field carried by the solar wind as it flows past Mars, which
generates an electric field, much as a turbine on Earth can be used to
generate electricity. This electric field accelerates electrically charged gas
atoms, called ions, in Mars' upper atmosphere and shoots them into space.[47]
The MAVEN mission measured the rate of atmospheric stripping at about 100
grams (≈1/4 lb) per second.[48]

### Moons and planetary
surfaces[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Solar_wind&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: Moons and planetary surfaces")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Aldrin_Next_to_Solar_Wind_Experiment_-
_GPN-2000-001211.jpg/170px-Aldrin_Next_to_Solar_Wind_Experiment_-
_GPN-2000-001211.jpg)](/wiki/File:Aldrin_Next_to_Solar_Wind_Experiment_-
_GPN-2000-001211.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Aldrin_Next_to_Solar_Wind_Experiment_-_GPN-2000-001211.jpg
"Enlarge")

Apollo's [SWC](/wiki/Solar_Wind_Composition_Experiment "Solar Wind Composition
Experiment") experiment

[Mercury](/wiki/Mercury_\(planet\) "Mercury \(planet\)"), the nearest planet
to the Sun, bears the full brunt of the solar wind, and since its atmosphere
is vestigial and transient, its surface is bathed in radiation.

Mercury has an intrinsic magnetic field, so under normal solar wind
conditions, the solar wind cannot penetrate its magnetosphere and particles
only reach the surface in the cusp regions. During coronal mass ejections,
however, the magnetopause may get pressed into the surface of the planet, and
under these conditions, the solar wind may interact freely with the planetary
surface.

The Earth's [Moon](/wiki/Moon "Moon") has no atmosphere or intrinsic [magnetic
field](/wiki/Magnetosphere "Magnetosphere"), and consequently its surface is
bombarded with the full solar wind. The [Project Apollo
missions](/wiki/Apollo_program "Apollo program") deployed passive aluminum
collectors in an attempt to sample the solar wind, and lunar soil returned for
study confirmed that the lunar [regolith](/wiki/Regolith "Regolith") is
enriched in atomic nuclei deposited from the solar wind. These elements may
prove useful resources for lunar colonies.[49]

## Outer limits[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Solar_wind&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Outer limits")]

Main article: [Heliopause (astronomy)](/wiki/Heliopause_\(astronomy\)
"Heliopause \(astronomy\)")

The solar wind "blows a bubble" in the [interstellar
medium](/wiki/Interstellar_medium "Interstellar medium") (the rarefied
hydrogen and helium gas that permeates the galaxy). The point where the solar
wind's strength is no longer great enough to push back the interstellar medium
is known as the [heliopause](/wiki/Heliosphere "Heliosphere") and is often
considered to be the outer border of the Solar System. The distance to the
heliopause is not precisely known and probably depends on the current velocity
of the solar wind and the local density of the interstellar medium, but it is
far outside [Pluto](/wiki/Pluto "Pluto")'s orbit. Scientists hope to gain
perspective on the heliopause from data acquired through the [Interstellar
Boundary Explorer](/wiki/Interstellar_Boundary_Explorer "Interstellar Boundary
Explorer") (IBEX) mission, launched in October 2008.

## Notable events[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Solar_wind&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Notable events")]

  * From May 10 to May 12, 1999, NASA's [Advanced Composition Explorer](/wiki/Advanced_Composition_Explorer "Advanced Composition Explorer") (ACE) and [WIND](/wiki/WIND_\(spacecraft\) "WIND \(spacecraft\)") spacecraft observed a 98% decrease of solar wind density. This allowed energetic electrons from the Sun to flow to Earth in narrow beams known as "[strahl](/wiki/Strahl_\(astronomy\) "Strahl \(astronomy\)")", which caused a highly unusual "polar rain" event, in which a visible [aurora](/wiki/Aurora_\(astronomy\) "Aurora \(astronomy\)") appeared over the North Pole. In addition, Earth's magnetosphere increased to between 5 and 6 times its normal size.[50]
  * On 13 December 2010, _[Voyager 1](/wiki/Voyager_1 "Voyager 1")_ determined that the velocity of the solar wind, at its location 10.8 billion miles (17.4 billion km) from Earth had slowed to zero. "We have gotten to the point where the wind from the Sun, which until now has always had an outward motion, is no longer moving outward; it is only moving sideways so that it can end up going down the tail of the heliosphere, which is a comet-shaped-like object," said Voyager project scientist Edward Stone.[51][52]
